name: Avial
history: Avial is a traditional dish from the South Indian state of Kerala, but it's also popular in Tamil Nadu and Karnataka. It's believed to have been invented by Bhima, one of the Pandava brothers from the Indian epic Mahabharata, during their exile.
description: Avial is a thick mixture of vegetables and coconut, seasoned with coconut oil and curry leaves. This dish is characterized by its variety of vegetables, subtle flavors, and the use of coconut and curd, which give it a creamy texture.

instructions.title: Cook the Vegetables
instructions.description: Cook the carrots, green beans, drumstick, raw banana, and yam in a pot with a little water, turmeric powder, and salt until they are soft but not mushy.

instructions.title: Grind Coconut Mixture
instructions.description: Grind the grated coconut, green chilies, and cumin seeds into a coarse paste.

instructions.title: Combine Ingredients
instructions.description: Add the coconut mixture to the cooked vegetables. Mix well and cook for a few minutes.

instructions.title: Add Curd and Season
instructions.description: Turn off the heat and add curd. Mix well. Heat coconut oil in a small pan, add curry leaves, and pour over the Avial.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Avial hot with rice.

tips: Ensure the vegetables are cut uniformly for even cooking.
Adjust the amount of green chilies based on your spice preference.
variations: Add other vegetables like pumpkin or squash for variation.
Replace curd with tamarind pulp for a tangier version.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat on the stove over low heat until warm. Do not overheat to prevent curdling of the curd.

presentationTips: Serve in a traditional earthenware dish for an authentic look.
Garnish with extra curry leaves for added aroma and visual appeal.
